Dr THEOPHANOUS (Calwell) (4.00 p.m.)--In this debate on the motion to take note of the paper on East Timor we are dealing with one of the most serious issues that we have had to face as a nation for a long time. All of the House supports the resolution of the United Nations Security Council on 15 September. In this House there has obviously been a discussion of the issues and of what led to the events in East Timor. Even today in question time, we had the Prime Minister making certain statements in relation to the matter. He did make the point that governments of various persuasions over the last 25 years or so have been responsible for far too much acceptance of what has been happening in East Timor and the role of the Indonesian military and the Indonesian government in East Timor. I think that is a correct proposition. But he also went on to imply that, because government had done this, somehow all parliamentarians had been of the same view, and that is not true. That important point needs to go on the record. In fact, from time to time a large number of parliamentarians----obviously not the majority-on both sides of the House have raised concerns about East Timor. The Parliamentarians for East Timor group of the parliament raised issues in relation to the Timor question. Today, the Leader of the Opposition referred to a comment by the Prime Minister in which he said that he criticised the left of Australian politics in 1985 in relation to their attitude to East Timor. The Prime Minister, in his reply to the Leader of the Opposition, did not actually deal with the question. He referred to the fact that governments of both persuasions had a certain position but he did not address the fact that there were many people, not just on the left I might say-although a lot of them were on the left of Australian politics-who expressed concerns in the community and in parliament in relation to the matter. Therefore, I have to say that what has happened in the Timor crisis is a salutary lesson about the excessive influence of the executive over parliament. There were concerned people on both sides of parliament and they were not able, irrespective of who was in government, to get their message or ideas across that things were wrong in terms of human rights and what was actually happening to the people of East Timor. We have to ask ourselves whether in these foreign policy areas there ought not to be a greater assertion of the role of parliament over government, irrespective of who is in government. In Westminster, foreign policy is discussed much more than it is in our parliament, and issues offoreign policy do need to be debated and dealt -th by parliamentarians. We do have our foreign affairs committees and the like-and I have participated in those committees for a long time-nevertheless, I think that it is very important that parliament asserts its authority in these matters because we can make mistakes. And in the case of East Timor, even in recent times, we have made mistakes. A lot has been written about the Labor Party's recent position on East Timor, and it has been asserted that there was a very recent conversion to that position. But the facts of the matter . REPRESENTATIVES MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Parliamentary Service Bill

speaker: Mr Deputy Speaker ( Mr Nehl) Took The Chair At 4.00 P.m.
theText: Monday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10675 are these: in April 1998 I moved a motion in the full caucus of the Labor Party which was seconded by the shadow foreign minister in which there was a significant shift from the position which Labor had held before then in relation to East Timor. That significant shift was then followed up by the shadow foreign minister in a number of important speeches in which he explained where we were coming from-that is, the Labor Party since that time-in relation to events in East Timor. Hardly anyone could have seen the dramatic nature of these events, but it is true that the Labor Party's change of position predated the announcements by President Habibie and the others in relation to the referendum and to the choice that was supposedly offered to the people of East Timor. Many people in this debate have spoken about the failure of the government to actually foresee what would happen following the referendum, and I think there is a point that needs to be made about this. We have an expert Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade but a department which is culturally dominated by certain attitudes. And what they brought to bear in this case was this: a certain culturally biased view. Because in Western democracies, or at least in democracies such as the United States, Canada, Australia and New Zealand-English speaking democracies, let us call them-people, generally speaking, accept a referendum result, they wrongly assumed that this was going to happen in East Timor. It was not what happened. If they had been sensitive to the intelligence which they received and, more importantly, to the cultural milieu in which these events were taking place, they would have realised that, just because a referendum passed, it does not follow that those who lose the referendum are going to automatically accept the result and go off peacefully. It was this cultural failure to understand people of a different background and what their response was likely to be in this matter which led to false propositions, not merely on the part of the government but on the part of the advisers to the government in foreign affairs. Maybe in the multicultural society we have in Australia we should get some government advisers in the department of foreign affairs who are broader in their cultural outlook, who understand that the reactions are not always the same. If we had done that, if we had understood the Indonesian psyche-where they were coming from, what they were encouraging in terms of the East Timorese-we might have recognised that we were facing an extremely dangerous situation and that we should avoid it. I think this is a lesson which we have to take on board straight away, because we will make further errors if we bring to this exercise a mentality and an approach which is culturally vety narrow, which presupposes that other people behave and act, notwithstanding their cultural background, in the same way, for example, as people in English speaking democracies do. Therefore we should try to make our foreign policy more sensitive to the cultural situation, to the understanding that other people have and not merely to the understanding that we bring to it. We are facing very dangerous times in East Timor. It is not clear what is going to happen, especially in Indonesia where it is possible that there could be a coup. Even if there is not a coup, the government itself, when it is elected-if there is an elected government-may persist in a policy which is detrimental to the people of East Timor. That may happen; I hope that it does not. Australia has to be sensitive every step of the way in this process. Not only do we have to support democracy in Indonesia; we also have to support those progressive forces that want to have an arrangement between Indonesia, East Timor and Australia. That should be our goal, and we should approach that goal with sensitivity to the people of Indonesia, who -!". ft ,.. REPRESENTATIVEMAIN COMMITTEE I , 10676 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 are caught up in a battle for their own democratic rights. This is a very important matter. (Time expired). tragedy that is East Timor, our involvement in the conflict, the suffering of the East Timorese people and the cruelty inflicted by the militia on the defenceless East Timorese people. I rise today for the same reason-to enforce the importance of the Prime Minister's decision to send our troops to East Timor. Firm commitments have already been given by a number of countries to support the international peacekeeping mission and others, such as the Republic of Korea and Sri Lanka, are considering making a contribution. Since our troops landed in Dili, they have been involved in minor incidents with members of the militia and members of the Indonesian defence force. Thankfully, to date all Australians are safe and well as. they continue in their peacekeeping role. This is our nation's largest military involvement for more than 30 years and our most sensitive. Some individuals in the community are asking how the federal government could send these young soldiers to East Timor. How could we send our young men and women to a country where, at present, there does not appear to be any regard, or care, for the lives of anyone or anything? Others raise the issue of the growing discontent of some Indonesians-they do not want Australian Army personnel there and many of them have a hatred of the 'colonials' who have entered their country and taken over. Questions continued to be raised when President Habibie agreed to allow our troops to enter East Timor on the condition that a majority of them be Asian in appearance. The answer to why the federal government persisted in leading a multinational force into East Timor, even after all of these issues were raised, was that it was requested to do so by the United Nations Security Council. That is not to say that committing our defence personnel was not a carefully measured, well-thought-out decision on the part of the government. I am positive that the Prime Minister agonised over which was the right course to take. To his credit, he made the right decision. And, yes, we have all thought about what it would be like to send young Australians off into dangerous conflict. We have to remember that our defence personnel have received the best possible training to handle this mission. In fact, the Australian Defence Force is at the highest point of readiness since the Vietnam War. Our Defence Force was aware this conflict was coming and, in June this year, began preparations. Preparations began with the increase in training and operational readiness of a brigade-size force in Darwin. It was this preparation that enabled us to respond with the speed and agility with which we did, and it is a testament to the profes!lionalism of the Defence Force that we were able to do so. We were able to react because our Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs were closely monitoring the situation prior to and following the results of the independence ballot on 30 August, a ballot which clearly showed the people of East Timor's desire for independence and freedom. The initial deployment to East Timor included land forces of brigade strength, logistic support elements, rotary wing support, air support and naval components. We have entered this difficult task well prepared, with every faith in the men and women who represent us in East Timor. We were so well prepared that we took on the role of leading the multinational force and are leading this force, I have to say, with the confidence and enthusiasm of a country well aware of and dedicated to achieving its goals, whatever the sacrifice.
title: Parliamentary Service Bill

speaker: Mr Schultz (Hume) (4.10 P.m.)
theText: Many of my colleagues have risen to discuss theMonday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10677 The maturity and success with which the Australian troops are handling this crisis make it difficult to believe that it is the first time Australia has been given the task of building and leading a multinational force on behalf of the United Nations. Most of you would have seen media images of our soldiers with their heads high, weapons ready and protective transport lumbering behind them. I recall the vision on TV of our armed forces carrying the Australian flag through the streets ofDili. Any country that called Australia lazy, complacent or uncaring can retrace their steps and rethink their view, for Australia, in one swoop, is proving its commitment to neighbouring countries, its commitment to peace and, most of all, its commitment to the security of all Australians. Nobody wants conflict; nobody wants the threat of war, but we have to accept that differing views will sometimes, unfortunately, lead to violence. In UN Security Council Resolution 1264, which was adopted unanimously on 15 September 1999, INTERFET has been mandated to restore peace and security in East Timor, protect and support UNAMET and facilitate humanitarian assisted operations. That is exactly what we are doing. We are leading a strong force of international soldiers to the resurrection of a country and to ease the suffering of thousands of human beings. Sacrifices that we have made by risking the lives of a maximum of 4,500 of our men and women will ease the suffering of thousands of others. Let us make no mistake about this. Our prime objective is to restore peace and allow the people of East Timor to enjoy the independence that they have sought for so long and which now, at the highest price, is in their grasp. To use the words of our defence minister, it is also in the interests of our national security to provide support in East Timor. We in Australia continue to enjoy our oppression free democratic lifestyles. Yet we still have some idea of what the East Timorese people are experiencing. Media coverage has shown us that. But can we or do we ever really want to understand it? Do we want to know what it is like to pass armed individuals walking the streets casually killing with callous disregard for human life? Worse yet, do we want to watch our loved ones slaughtered, their only crime a desire for freedom-Jreedom which we enjoy every moment of every day? Of course we do not. It is only when we really try to visualise and feel what these individuals are experiencing that we begin to understand the importance of this peacekeeping mission. Our troops will venture home, scarred by memories, but able to continue with their lives. These soldiers will appreciate their existence in the Lucky Country and will occasionally give thought to the notion that it was their bravery and commitment that removed a threat to the peaceful existence of the East Timorese. The people of East Timor will always remember the commitment by Australians. However, many of them will never recover from the atrocities meted out by the militia and sections of the Indonesian army. It is our decision as a strong country to try to ease their pain and, if possible, allow them to begin to gain what we have taken for granted since Federation-freedom. Since Federation, Australia has developed a network of security related alliances, treaties and agreements. Australia's relationships with the United States, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and Canada are close and enduring. Shared history and a common commitment to Western democratic ideals strengthen these relationships. Also of fundamental importance to Australia's security are its regional relationships, particularly with the nations of South-East Asia and the south-west Pacific. 10678 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 In support of these collective defence arrangements is a wider security architecture of collective security, common security and other multilateral agreements. The maintenance and development of these relationships are enduring features of the way in which Defence seeks to protect Australia, its people and interests. The Army's professional competence and reliability has been a key element in forging and building these relationships. Furthermore, the deployment of ground troops to counter aggression is the ultimate demonstration of commitment to support friends and allies. By 29 September, as the leaders of the multinational force, we will, at the calling of resolution 1264, provide a progressive report to the UN Security Council on the situation in East Timor. We have just two days until this deadline and, in my view, the report looks good. This report mayor may not recommend that more troops from Australia enter East Timor. Either way, the decision will be based on our success at undertaking the mandate given by the UN. The multinational force has been successful in carrying out the guidelines of the mandate so far, but this does not mean that death and destruction has, or will, cease. Hitting the headlines recently was the callous, unthinkable execution style murder of a Dutch journalist on the outskirts of DilL This journalist, while sadly just one of the hundreds killed by the militia or Indonesian forces, served as a warning symbol to our media and, indeed, to the nation. This man had a family, friends and coworkers and he died because he was trying to keep his countrymen informed of what was happening in this atrocious abuse of civil liberties. These forces, part militia and part Indonesian army, hell-bent on denying freedom and independence to East Timor, will not give up easily and have no regard for the lives of others. Rather than allow independence or freedom, these poor excuses for human beings would prefer to see thousands of innocent men, women and children killed or maimed and mutilated. I hope that the cowards carrying out these murders are, at the moment, confused, scared and feeling threatened by the presence of armed, well-equipped peacekeepers. The evidence provided, however, suggests they are evil, arrogant and dismissive of this show of strength. As evidence, I refer to the grizzly discovery of several bodies and further confirmation of torture that has taken place in and around Dili. This murderous abuse of many East Timorese people is occurring in an environment where our troops have not yet begun the most dangerous component of their mission. As they scour the outskirts of Dili and enter small villages and provinces within East Timor, they are sure to find more evidence of death and destruction and will inevitably clash with forces wanting to kill as a symbol of some kind of sick victory. I know a lot of the issues I have raised today are echoing the thoughts and feelings of many of my colleagues who have already risen on this subject. What our troops need now, while working towards their goals in East Timor, is our support, our encouragement and our confidence in their ability to succeed in carrying out the UN mandate and to complete it without further loss of life. We cannot question the decision of the coalition government; we cannot question our troops' ability; and we certainly cannot question the reasons associated with the deployment of peacekeeping troops into East Timor. (Time expired) of guilt that Australians, under governments of both political persuasions, have let the East Timorese people down badly from the time that we left them to the mercy of the Japanese forces in 1942, to the present period when Australia and the United Nations have failed to keep their promise to provide protection for the East Timorese people after the independence ballot.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Mossfield (Greenway) (4.20 P.m.}
theText: I think we all speak in this debate with a feelingMonday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10679 However, all Australians would have welcomed the Indonesian government's decision to invite an international peacekeeping force into East Timor, while expressing our horror at the continual suffering of the East Timorese people. The point of my rising in this debate is to indicate on behalf of all Greenway residents our absolute support for the remaining people in East Timor and for the multinational peacekeeping force. I say 'remaining people' because the militia has indiscriminately slaughtered so many of the population. Not only ordinary people were killed but also several nuns and priests were killed, including the General Secretary of the Christian Church in East Timor. Other church figures such as Bishop Belo and Bishop Nascimento were forced out of their homes and had to flee for their lives. These attacks on religious people and on the Timorese, who had the courage to vote for their own democratic state, are as bad as anything that was witnessed by the victims of, and undertaken by, the Third Reich during World War II. As we sat in front of our TV sets or listened to the radio or looked at the press pictures, we must all have been experiencing real horror and absolute disgust that these outrages could have been taking place. We should particularly thank the media for their detailed coverage of this ongoing disaster so close to our shores. Some of these people have already suffered with the loss of their lives. At the same time, we must be critical of the current government for its short-sighted decision to close down Radio Australia which robbed the East Timorese people of reliable news from the outside world during their crisis. Even more outrageous is the fact that the killings and mayhem appear to be supported by the Indonesian military. The failure of the Indonesian security forces to guarantee the safety of media representatives, United Nations and Red Cross workers, resulting in these people being forced to leave East Timor, would lead ordinary Australian citizens to believe that the Indonesian military was supporting a media blackout in East Timor to hide the atrocities that were being inflicted on the East Timorese people. The Indonesian military in East Timor has to accept its full responsibility for the atrocities that were committed in its name and committed by its supporters who were well armed by the military personnel, and who, it now appears, had never intended to accept the will of the people if it did not agree with their point of view. The Indonesian government should have told its military generals not only to stop the killings in Timor, but they should have been under instruction never to start the killings or to face all the penalties that murderers should face. The international community, now with the cooperation of the Indonesian government, must move quickly to ensure that the atrocities in East Timor do not go unpunished. The security and the health of the remaining people in East Timor must be our first consideration, then evidence must be collected quickly so that the appropriate legal action can be taken to ensure that breaches of international law are pursued. It is pleasing to note that Mary Robinson, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, has stated that the United Nations will establish a tribunal to investigate crimes committed in East Timor. It is probably a bit churlish of me to say that the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith has been vindicated in his many pronouncements on this issue. Nevertheless, I think it needs to be noted that the honourable member was in fact vigorously chided by the government on more than one occasion for his policy stand and I suspect he may have been chided by one or two prominent people from our side as well. I believe the important issue was that at least 10680 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 someone was raising the real prospects of what finally happened, and no one can say that they were surprised by the events following the successful ballot. The member for Kingsford-Smith stated in a press release on 3 September that a senior member of the pro-integrationist militia had said: "If the UNAMET announces that the pro-independence side has won the ballot I promise it will be civil war a g a in . ' "If the UN says that they have won then the pro-independence forces don't deserve to live any more because it is not fair ... I would go to war to slaughter all pro-independence people, because we will be sure that they have cheated." With this information available to the shadow minister, and being aware of the policy failures of previous Australian governments, why was this government caught so unprepared? With atrocities committed in East Timor by the Indonesian troops so well documented, such as the killing of the Australian journalists and the now infamous cemetery massacre, why was postreferendum East Timor going to be any different? The shadow minister for foreign affairs referred to several events that should have alerted the government to the tragic events that were likely to unfold in East Timor after the independence ballot. But the most poignant example was the case of Father Francisco Barreto. I quote from the honourable member's speech: Father Francisco Barreto sat in my office in Sydney. He came in his capacity as Director of Caritas in East Timor. He also called on the foreign minister in his plea for Australia to do what was required to guarantee security. He sat there and he told me of his dreadful foreboding of what was likely to happen to his people if they were left to the mercy of the militia and their military controllers. I saw him again in East Timor the day after the baIJot and the day before the parliamentary delegation returned to Australia. He repeated his fears. Tragically, his foreboding proved all too correct. He was one of the first of the Catholic priests to be assassinated by the militia following the announcement of the ballot results. Surely this man was one of the real heroes of East Timor. He in fact predicted his own death, yet he bravely returned to East Timor, having failed to obtain protection for the people that he represented. The Minister for Foreign Affairs did say in question time last week that the government did not anticipate the extent of the violence. This has been a major international crisis close to our shores and this government has been caught asleep on the job. I do not mind the government taking credit for what it has done, and that is that, once it decided to do something about East Timor, it moved quickly to get a multinational peacekeeping force together. But it would also have been nice for the government to have said that they were sorry that they did not do more to protect the East Timorese people after the independence ballot had been conducted, and so have saved many innocent lives. At least more diplomatic pressure should have been applied to the United Nations to provide adequate protection for their own staff. Hopefully, we can now be sure that, as we look towards a more peaceful future for East Timor, we will provide full protection for the people there and that we can ensure that they are provided with housing, food, bedding and other necessities of life. We must ensure that all of the people have access to emergency supplies. We must also ensure that the peacekeeping force knows that all Australians are giving them their full support. The trauma in East Timor was aided and abetted by a group of belligerent generals who were not restricted by their government, as they should have been. I join with my fellow members of parliament in mourning the loss of the many killed in Timor. I am thankful that there remain many valiant people in East Timor who will pick up their lives again, with help from us and Monday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10681 from other equally caring nations. On behalf of the people of my electorate of Greenway, I wish all members of the peacekeeping force in Timor a safe completion of their tour of duty and a speedy return to their home country and loved ones. . Ms BAILEY (McEwen) (4.30 p.m.)--Just a few weeks ago, the East',Timorese people voted in a democratic election to decide on their independence from Indonesia. The result was what we would describe as a landslide victory for independence with 78.6'per cent of the East Timorese people voting for independence. It must be remembered, Mr Deputy Speaker, that over 98 per cent of registered voters voted in what has been acknowledged by those international observers of the election process as a relatively calm environment. Members of this parliament, led by the Hon. Tim Fischer, who acted as observers of the election process, have reported on the lengths people went to to ensure their vote. They reported that before the polling booths opened people had voted in their thousands, often holding their registration cards and their photo IDs in full view. In some villages where polling booths were located, people returned to vote in areas where their homes had already been burnt to the ground by the militia. This is an extraordinary commitment and demonstrates the will of the East Timorese people to exercise their democratic rights. However, as the result of this democratic vote became known, that announcement marked the end of any peaceful environment on East Timor. Credit and congratulations must be given to the officials from the Australian Electoral Commission for the work that they have done, to the consular staff and in particular to our Australian Ambass-dor, Mr John McCarthy, who has worked courageously and tirelessly throughout this entire period and continues to provide valuable advice to the government. Hour by hour we heard reports of armed anti-independence militia killing innocent bystanders, burning buildings, looting and forcing people at gunpoint to leave their homes. We then saw evidence of these acts of unbridled violence on our nightly TV news. Anyone who heard of or saw these acts of atrocities on innocent and vulnerable people, including in the following days, acts of violence against children, nuns and priests, was horrified and repulsed by such senseless violence. This violence spread to the UN and other international staff. In anyone's language, these were totally unacceptable acts of violence by the militia and those within the Indonesian military who did not disarm and stop the killing by the militia. Human rights were swept aside in this tide of violence and brutality. Australia did not shirk from its responsibilities in assisting the East Timorese gaining the opportunity to have their say in determining their future in a democratic election. Australia has not shirked its responsibility in coming to the assistance of the East Timorese in the aftermath of the election. When it became patently obvious that the Indonesian government could not or would not control the militia, many people both here in Australia and throughout the world demanded that something be done. Many people from my own electorate contacted me urging the government to do something. The reality was that' neither Australia nor any other nation could send in peacekeeping forces to bring the militia under control and stop the killings without the permission of the country they would have to enter. To do otherwise would be regarded as invasion. Instead of our troops entering the country as peacemakers, they would be seen as hostile invaders and treated accordingly. The facts as now revealed show that Australia, through the leadership and drive of our Prime Minister and so well assisted by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and the Minister for Defence, achieved the agreement of Indonesia to accept an international peacekeeping force and the 10682 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 involvement of the UN. On 16 September, the United Nations Security Council voted unanimously for a resolution to establish an Australian-led multinational peacekeeping force for East Timor, known as INTERFET. The swiftness of this decision by the Security Council is testimony to Australia's detennination and the acknowledgment of the seriousness of the situation by the UN Security Council, not known as having a record for such swift action. Major General Peter Cosgrove commands INTERFET, with Thailand providing his deputy. New Zealand, the United States, the United Kingdom, Italy, Canada, the Philippines, Malaysia, Singapore, France, Brazil and Ireland are all members of the coalition. While these negotiations were being pursued, Australia was also providing humanitarian assistance by airlifting homeless and displaced East Timorese and UN workers and aid personnel, as well as organising food drops to areas where people forced to flee their villages had sought refuge. I am sure that most of us saw those horrific scenes on television where parents passed their children across barbed wire fences into the safety of the UNAMET compound. Many of those children are now being cared for at the Puckapunyal any base in my electorate. I was there to welcome them and other family members who were airlifted out of Dili. I shall never forget their faces as they were assisted off the buses on arrival at Puckapunyal. Many of the children were unwell and were showing obvious signs of lack of nourishment. There are currently over 800 refugees being cared for at Puckapunyal. I want to place on record the simply outstanding job that the following people are doing: Megan McCrae and her team from DIMA, Major Blu Horton and his defence personnel, Jenny Oakley and her helpers at the neighbourhood house and the hundreds of locals who have been so generous in donating goods, services and their time. People from all over my electorate, whose generosity was spontaneous and overwhelming with the Kosovar refugees, are displaying the same level of concern and desire to help. It has been impossible to estimate exactly how many East Timorese have been made homeless and are at risk because of the violence of the militia, but it is thought to be in the hundreds of thousands of people. Australia has taken the lead not just in providing the humanitarian assistance that I have already detailed but also in assisting UN agencies to provide assistance directly to where it is needed in the shortest possible time, and making Darwin the jump-off point for international relief operations and warehouse facilities for storage, both for Australian donations and international relief supplies. As well as these efforts, Australia is making every effort to gain access to displaced East Timorese in West Timor. The Australian effort to restore peace and security in East Timor is the largest military involvement for more than 30 years, with an initial task force of 2,000 but with the capacity to increase this to 4,500, if necessary. As the Prime Minister has said, 'Our soldiers go to East Timor as part of a great Australian ... tradition, which has never . s-)Ught to impose the will of this country on others, but only to defend what is right.' It has always been our objective to ensure that the will of the East Timorese in voting for their independence so overwhelmingly on 30 August be allowed to take effect in a stable and secure environment. Our concern also, of course, is for our troops, who have been given the task to achieve this outcome. I Was particularly pleased that the government has increased entitlements to our troops in recognition of the level of their deployment and, importantly, it has provided , the highest level of support to their families with a national welfare coordination centre being established to provide a 24-hour point Of contact for families . ., .. ' " ,I , REPRESENTATIVES MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10683 This is a tragedy that continues to unfold for a gentle and peaceful people. We must, and we will, maintain every effort to see these people re-established in their own country in peace and security. of Wills, I wish to extend to the people of East Timor our acute sense of distress and grief at that which they have been experiencing in recent times and, of course, in many respects for the best part of 25 years. It is extraordinarily difficult for us to contemplate the magnitude of the horrors that people in that place have been through and, indeed, to reflect on how difficult it will be for them to rebuild their community and rebuild their society. I feel obliged to offer an apology on behalf of all of us who have been involved in the political process. While I think we should be careful about wallowing in blame, we should understand that it is the Indonesian military who have been primarily responsible for this tragedy, for this debacle. All of us who are involved in politics, people involved in the media, and people involved in other aspects of public life, must share some responsibility for what has occurred here because there is no doubt that to some extent the people of East Timor have been effectively lured into a trap and that they have suffered grievously as a result. What has occurred in East Timor leads me to make some sad reflections on human nature and the fact that people are still prepared to kill and torture others in cold blood. Some of my earliest political views were formed as a student of history and politics at the University of Melbourne. We used to study and reflect on things that had occurred back in the first part of this century, particularly things that had occurred in the Soviet Union with the rise of communism and the work of Lenin and Stalin and others in that place. We also used to study the rise of Hitler and the Weimar Republic and things that occurred during the Second World War, and events such as the Spanish Civil War, the conflict between the nationalist and communist forces in China, and so on. It was appalling, bloodcurdling, to realise what people were prepared to do to each other as part of these political conflicts. But, when I reflect on these things, I used to think of them as things of the past, as things that belonged to a different time. I used to think that in some ways we had learned from these dreadful experiences and had become more civilised as a result. However, when we see what has occurred in East Timor and, indeed, in other places in recent years as well, we realise that this has not occurred and we have to make some pretty sad reflections. on human nature. I want to make a few brief points about this tragedy as I see it. I want to borrow to some extent from the work of Gareth Evans, who is uniquely qualified to comment on some of the history of the situation that we now find ourselves in. If we look back on the past years, one of the points that ought to be made is that Australia was not in a position militarily to stop or reverse Indonesia's invasion of East Timor in 1975, and neither were we in a position to move in unilaterally, against Indonesia's will, to stop the recent carnage. Perhaps we could have done more back in 1975 to try to discourage Suharto at that time, but there is very little reason to believe that it would have made any practical difference. There was very little international enthusiasm for getting involved in another conflict in Asia in the wake of the Vietnam War, and it seems highly likely that the Indonesians would have invaded East Timor irrespective of our views. The de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor has been the subject of quite a lot of comment. I think it ought to be recalled and remembered that Australia continued to recognise East Timor as a non-self-governing territory entitled to self-determination. That
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Kelvin Thomson (Wills) (4.39 P.m.)
theText: On behalf of the people of the electorate10684 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 was its status under Portuguese sovereignty and it continues to be the case under Indonesian sovereignty. We ought to be aware that, before the economic crisis of 1997, with its political aftermath which changed everything, there seemed to be absolutely no realistic prospect that Indonesia would ever actually agree to a fully-fledged act of self-determination on the part of the East Timorese in which independence was an option. I think people who followed that period closely would accept that. Of course, after 1997, this all changed dramatically and the economic crisis saw Indonesia coming under a great deal of international pressure and being very keen to get international support. So, with Suharto's downfall, we did see these new options for the resolution of the East Timor situation open up. As part of that, it should be noted that, at the time, those calling for independence-for example, Xanana Gusmao and then Jose Ramos Horta and Bishop Belo---talked about a decade of autonomy before a referendum on independence was held. Those East Timorese leaders knew all too well the potential for violence if things were rushed and handled poorly. The next point that ought to be made is that a great deal more could have been done to work for better security for the East Timorese during the ballot process and its aftermath. Clearly, what went on put the safety of pro-independence supporters horribly at risk. But we did not try in this area-and, indeed, we sought to dissuade other countries from pursuing the peacekeeping options. We should have done more with the US, but I guess we will never know whether that would have changed things because we never really tried. There are these issues of the past: whether we should have had this ballot on independence without East Timor going through a substantial period of autonomy; whether we should have proceeded with the ballot in the absence of proper protections for the preservation of physical security; and also the length of time that it took us to get the peacekeepers in there. But what we have to do now is to look to the future. In looking to the future, there are a few points that I think are very important. Firstly, we have to understand that our quarrel in East Timor is with the Indonesian military, not with its government, not with its people. I think some of the protests that have been made in terms of picketing embassies, bans on Garuda and so on, miss the point in this regard. Secondly, we are leading the United Nations military operation because we reflect the collective concern of the whole international community. As Gareth Evans said: We shouldn't be spooked by the strident claims of some Indonesian spokespersons ... that Australia is playing regional policeman out of colonialist instinct and residual racist sentiment. Nothing could be further from the truth. Indeed, I want to say, as forcefully as I can, that there is no such thing as Asian human rights and other people's human rights. There are universal human rights and universal values. Next, I think we should still see our security interests as being best pursued with Indonesia and our Asian neighbours rather than against them. When this is all over-and it may take a very long time before it is all over-they will still be there and it is absolutely essential that we continue to have good relations with Indonesia and the other countries of the region. As I said at the outset, I feel-and I know that many people in the electorate of Wills who have contacted me feel-a great sense of grief and distress at what has happened to the people of East Timor during recent times. Our hearts go out to them and I am pleased to have had the opportunity to contribute to this debate in support of the UN resolution. Monday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10685 to have this chance to comment on what is undoubtedly the biggest defence and foreign policy challenge that Australia has faced in a generation. Ben Chifley's 'light on the hill' was, he said, to work for the betterment of mankind, not just here but wherever we could lend a helping hand. It seems to me that Australia's intervention in East Timor stands in the great tradition of one of our greatest Prime Ministers. In 1949, when the people oflndonesia were fighting to be free, the Australian government refused to support the Dutch colonial occupation and laid the basis of what should be a lasting friendship between Australia and the peoples of Indonesia. The tragedy of East Timor, which the Indonesian establishment, and particularly the Indonesian militruy establishment, seems never to have grasped, was that the Indonesians were every bit as much colonial overlords there as the Dutch had been in Indonesia itself. From 1975, Australian policy towards the forcible integration of East Timor into Indonesia has been that of an awkward and embarrassed bystander. For understandable reasons, we did not want our moral qualms to affect good relations with our giant neighbour, but you cannot have business as usual when people are being slaughtered in the street. I think the vast majority of Australians-and, I suspect, the vast majority of Indonesians-are actually relieved that an ignominious chapter in history seems now to have closed. If, as I hope, East Timor becomes a free, stable and democratic society, two people deserve considerable credit. The first is President B.J. Habibie, who realised that Indonesia's hold on people who did not want to belong was politically, economically and ultimately morally untenable, and thus permitted the United Nations ballot. The second is Prime Minister J.W. Howard, who could easily have dithered on the sidelines like so many of his predecessors, or, like the Pharisee, passed by on the other side of the road. Instead, he organised the multinational force which is now giving the people of East Timor the protection they are entitled to expect. A few voices have suggested that Australia should have let the Indonesians sort things out in their own way, as if the slaughter of innocents has ever been a part of any culture's ordinary way of doing things. A few voices have even suggested that Australia is trying to impose Western values. As the previous speaker, the member for Wills, has said, this is dead wrong. Australia is standing up for universal human values, values which are every bit as much Indonesian values as they are Australian values. When President Habibie sanctioned the free vote he was standing up for the best values of the Indonesian people, and when John Howard organised a force to stop the slaughter he was standing up for the best values of the Australian as well as the Indonesian people-values which had been forgotten, it seems, by rogue elements inside the Indonesian militruy. There have been times when Australia has committed more troops abroad. Obviously, the 300,000 who went abroad as part of the 1st and 2nd AIF had a much bigger role in conflict than the peacekeeping force. There have been times when Australia has made a bigger impact on world history-for instance, in March 1918 when the 1st AIF stopped the big German push, and in 1941 when the 2nd AIF virtually knocked Italy out of the war. But never before has Australia, in its own right, stood in this way for justice and freedom. We have never been a leader in any international expedition in this way. The UN resolution was our doing; the multinational army is our doing. None of this would have happened without us.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Abbott (Warringah
theText: Minister for Employment Services) (4.49 p.m.)-I am grateful10686 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 There are some voices raised now to say that, because of what is happening in East Timor, Australia is the odd man out of Asia. On the contrary, we have never had more friends than since we decided to take our stand for justice and freedom for a people denied both for far too long. As well as Australia, Thailand, New Zealand, the United States, Italy, Canada, the Philippines, Malaysia, Singapore, France, Brazil and the United Kingdom are contributing to the force in East Timor. In addition, Fiji, Pakistan, Zimbabwe, Egypt, Mozambique, Spain, Ireland, Denmark, Japan and Portugal are assisting in other ways. The People's Republic of China is making a small but significant contribution. All this is happening because our government and our Prime Minister decided that we had dithered on the sidelines for too long. Our government and our Prime Minister decided that Australia had to lead on behalf of the suffering people of East Timor. I doubt that Australia has ever stood taller in our region. Certainly, I have rarely felt more proud to be an Australian; proud to be an Australian and humbled at the exertions of our soldiers who are standing up for decent, civilised values on behalf of the Australian and Indonesian people. I just want to close with a few observations about the way this debate has been conducted in Australia. I regret to say that on this issue the Leader of the Opposition, who is a decent man, has blown a tin trumpet. It is as if Neville Chamberlain of 1938 was pretending that he, too, would have been Winston Churchill in 1940. He seems to be saying that we should have kept good relations with Indonesia while at the same time we should have labelled them an international pariah before the ballot and its aftermath. He seems to be saying that we should have known that elements of the Indonesian army would go on the rampage and we should have insisted on armed peacekeepers before the ballot, even though he must know that this would have resulted in the ballot's immediate cancellation. It seems to me that on this issue at times Kim Beazley and General Wiranto seemed to have formed a unity ticket. The result of the Beazley line is that East Timor would have remained an Indonesian killing field and a blot on Australia's conscience for ever. today concerns a horrific situation in East Timor at the moment where virtually the entire infrastructure of the island has been destroyed. The country that was there previously, with its own designation as a territory within Indonesia, has been virtually wiped away. Australian troops are now serving with the INTERFET force in a country where most of the population has been displaced. It is a country where at least 200,000 people in the past 25 years have been killed by the occupying Indonesian forces. It is a country where the militias numbered two just over a year ago. Those militias now number 13. They cover every region of East Timor. Minister indicated in his speech on this matter-that some elements or rogue elements within the Indonesian military forces were responsible for helping the militia does not bear even the slightest or most marginal examination. The deliberateness with which the Indonesian armed forces have gone about increasing the number of militia, from two to 13-increasing its geographic spread from Ii part of East Timor to every region of East Timor-and the manner in which they have conspired and colluded to drive the anti-independence militia campaigns, has been, and should have been, evident to this government before they made their major decisions.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Hatton (Blaxland) (4.57 P.m.)
theText: The motion to take note of the paper in front of us
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: The Notion Brought Up By The Minister For Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer
theText: and as the PrimeMonday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10687 As our shadow minister for foreign affairs has indicated, there was ample evidence before the government throughout this year and prior to that that the Indonesian military were in a position where they determined their position in case East Timor should become independent. Effectively, that position was to raze the land to nothing, to displace its peoples, or to do away with them through the agency of the militias. The argument of the Prime Minister that there has been only one course to follow-only one reasonable, sensible course in all of this-is open to question. It is open to question in particular because of the misreading of history, either deliberate or unintended, that has been at the back of what should have been an informed view of what the intentions of the Indonesian military and the Indonesian government were. In 1965, during the period of time when there was a problem throughout the archipelago of Indonesia with the Indonesian Communist Party-from memory, the PKI-there were about 750,000 people killed by the Indonesian military in order to put down what the military typified as a communist coup or an insurgency. Since that time, since the establishment of the Suharto government and the relative stability brought by the Indonesian military to every village, every small part of the Indonesian archipelago, that was imposed with immense and brutal force in the 1960s, not one person who has worked in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade over the past three decades would be unaware of that campaign. Not one person seeking to give advice to the government would be unaware of the long history of what has happened, not only in East Timor but in other places. Irian Jaya is very close to Australia, as is East Timor. Papua New Guinea is free; Irian Jaya is part of Indonesia. But because there has been virtually no media coverage of what has happened in Irian Jaya over the past many years, it does not come up as the slightest blip on the Australian radar. But the department of foreign affairs has background information in relation to what has happened in Irian Jaya and in other places in Indonesia-certainly, in the last year or so, as to what has been happening in Aceh, Ambon, Kalimantan and the great instability that is there since the fall of Suharto, since his replacement by President Habibie and since the Indonesian economy was flattened to the point that 30 years of work building that economy were wiped out overnight. This is an unstable and difficult economic, political and social environment that the Indonesian government faces. The move towards democratic elections, despite the result, still hangs in the balance, and it hangs in the balance because the military still have an effective control over what happens in that parliament. Nothing demonstrates it better than what has happened in East Timor in the past year. And it is demonstrated absolutely when'you look at the fact that they have been able to turn the militias on and off at will. The Prime Minister said it was just 'elements' of the military. The foreign minister repeatedly said they were simply 'rogue elements' of the military. During the election day, 78Y2 per cent of people bravely voted for independence, an independence vote that they were precipitously driven to by Foreign Minister Alatas and President Habibie, and which this government drove towards and pushed, against resistance from the leading East Timorese leaders who had cautioned time and again that the great problem in East Timor, for its people and for the country as a whole and its future, was its security and that, unless security was guaranteed in East Timor, what has happened would happen. All of those leaders warned in relation to that. 10688 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 As the shadow minister indicated, the Defence Intelligence Organisation did its job. It is not a secret that the United States listens in to every telephone call that is made in Australia. Equally, it is not a secret the Defence Intelligence Organisation has the capacity and has for many years been listening in to all communications within Indonesia and to the Indonesian military communications as well. That is how they have gained a lot of their information. All of the Western countries have that capacity. In fact, Australia gets information from the United States that it chooses to give us from its intelligence gathering activities, and we share our views with them. The Prime Minister and the foreign minister have argued that they could not have been prepared for what happened, that it could not have been predicted because there was very little information about what impact there would be after the independence vote. But, as Laurie Brereton pointed out on 23 September 1999 in his press release: The Shadow Minister. . . said today that the Australian Consulate in Dili received from UNAMET in early August, copies of documents detailing intimate cooperation between the Indonesian military and militias and their plans for widespread violence following the vote, including the mass deportation of population and liquidation of pro-independence East Timorese. That was in August of this year, before the ballot. In fact, if we look at what material was there, in one long paragraph there is a full indication of the Indonesian military cooperating with and organising the militias, planning what would happen if the independence vote was positive, and planning not only what they would do prior to it to try to disrupt it but what would happen afterwards. They laid out a plan for the devastation of that country and the destruction of the people. Our soldiers have entered into a very dangerous situation. It was argued by East Timorese leaders that foreign soldiers coming as a peacekeeping or peace enforcement force should have come in as soon as possible and that preparations should have been made before. Their preference was not fo be driven by Foreign Minister Alatas and Prime Minister Habibie and then the Australian government into a precipitate vote, but once that had happened, even though they wanted a long period of time, they said there needed to be a peacekeeping force straight away. Instead of that we had a wait of almost three weeks. The reasop for that is the Australian government's failure to properly interpret and take regard of all of the military intelligence that it had in front of it. I think they did not take that into account because they simply chose not t-. They chose not to because they placed their reading of the situation above the accurate information that was coming in, not just a small amount, but in droves from our intelligence sources. Mr SEeKER (Barker) (5.07 p.m.)-It pleases me to be given an opportunity to contribute to this debate on East Timor. I rise to speak on this motion sponsored by our Prime Minister, a motion which should receive the unanimous approval of iill Australians and this parliament. However, what has been noticeable is the cheap, unprincipled attacks by various members of the opposition from the top down. It is both disappointing and demeaning for Her Majesty's opposition to be seen to be behaving in such a way over a matter of such national importance. If the opposition leader had reasonable grounds for acting in such a way, it could be excused. But he does not. The opposition leader claims that there has been a policy failure and that he could have done better. He claims that the large measure of this destruction could have been avoided. The only way that that could have occurred was by invading Indonesia, Monday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10689 and surely he is not advocating that we should have invaded our nearest neighbour as an act of war. That sort of woolly thinking is naive and shallow, and the people of Australia deserve a lot better from such a representative of this parliament. It just does not follow that the United Nations would have acted before it did just because some people with the wisdom of hindsight suggest they saw it coming. Even the Leader of the Opposition himself said on 15 July this year that it was up to the United Nations to act, not Australia unilaterally. Anyone with any semblance of understanding of the United Nations would know that the Security Council would have had any action vetoed by at least one of its members, such as China or Russia, prior to the independence vote, or indeed before it actually did vote. This nation of approximately 800,000 people needs our support and we have given it. It is to the credit of our Prime Minister and our foreign minister, Alexander Downer, that we were able to obtain, on behalf of the East Timorese, a chapter 7 peacekeeping force on behalf of the United Nations in record time and without a veto. It is in our strategic interest to have a stable, secure and prosperous Indonesia and to ensure that the UN process in East Timor moves back on track so that the overwhelming will of the East Timorese for independence is obtained. It is also important to fulfil the humanitarian expectations of both the international community and the Australian population. Contrast this statesmanship with that of the opposition whose main contributors to policy making seem to come from a rabble of left wing journalists who were rightly taken to task by the Media Watch program on the ABC last Monday. They were taken to task for their lack of consistency and professionalism. They are bereft of policy and credibility to the Australian people. The member for Kingsford-Smith is no better in his role of shadow foreign affairs spokesman. To selectively leak details of confidential cables and briefings is not acceptable behaviour for a member of parliament. Just imagine if this had been done during any of the world wars. John Curtin would not stoop this low; Ben Chifley would not stoop this low; and even Gough Whitlam or Bob Hawke would not have stooped so low. Last SundayI had the pleasure of being the guest of the Murray Bridge RSL sub-branch. They were unanimous in their support for our government's actions and deeds. They were unanimous in their support for increased defence spending and a build-up of our defence forces. I was certainly left with the feeling that they did not want to move to a republic. President Habibie is to be congratulated for his actions in allowing a free vote for independence against considerable opposition from his own people and our government for its change in policy towards East Timor. Indeed, the shadow foreign affairs spokesman is to be congratulated for dragging the Labor Party out of its acquiescent attitude towards Indonesia. Indeed, the actions of our government and those of countries such as Thailand, New Zealand and others have been exemplary in their quick and forceful commitment to solving the problems of East Timor. It is to their shame that, when Australians need to be seen as united in their resolve, the opposition is seen to be cheap, unprincipled and derogatory. I add my best wishes for a safe return for all our brave soldiers that will act as a peacekeeping force in East Timor and for all those soldiers from other countries as well. I am sure that I can express the same sentiment on behalf of all the people in the seat of Barker. In my short time in this parliament I am pleased to report that this issue has caused the greatest reaction from within the electorate of Barker and, importantly, from the ordinary people of all ages within Barker. These were people who.would not ordinarily make representations to 10690 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 me, but they were good people who wanted to see an end to the injustices inflicted on the East Timorese. It pleases me that Australians still want a fair go for all the world's citizens, no matter what their colour or creed. We have taken the hard decisions. We have applied the right diplomatic pressure and we have planned this policy position correctly. Again, my best wishes to all our service men and women and God bless them. resolution on East Timor, firstly, I want to express my disappointment that I am speaking so late in the program when I had been led to believe that I would be speaking quite some time ago. I wonder whether or not that was accidental because part of my speech will be taken up with a report to this parliament, made back in October 1991, of a delegation of parliamentarians that visited Indonesia, including East Timor, earlier that year. That delegation to East Timor was led by the then Speaker of the parliament, the current member for Watson. The visit took place on 7 February 1991. The delegation included, as well as the then Speaker and me, the member for New England, Senator Macdonald, Garrie Gibson and John Riggall, who are ex-members. It was a very complex delegation dealing with very complex matters. It took quite some time before we finally tabled a report in October, some eight months after our return. That was partly because there was quite a lot of disagreement and discontent amongst committee members. It was quite difficult for us to formalise a final report. The report itself does incorporate a minority report on the question of East Timor. That minority report was tabled by me, Senator Sherry and Mr Gibson. For the record, it recommended that a conference convened by the United Nations consisting of all parties involved in the current dispute, including the governments of Portugal and Indonesia, be held as soon as possible; and, further, that the Australian government should directly pursue the recommendations, as outlined in the report, with the UN and the Indonesian government. That was a watered down version of what we had hoped for. We had hoped to get majority agreement on that. The three of us who submitted that report actually wanted an act of self determination, but unfortunately at the time the alliance of the then Speaker with the members of the then opposition meant that that did not occur. If it had, it no doubt would have gone further towards shifting the attitude within the government to which I belonged towards a recognition that the issues in East Timor were not going to go away. While we were there there was a demonstration, and I do not think anybody was surprised at the subsequent massacre that occurred later in the same year at the cemetery. It was obvious that the tension and pressure building up in East Timor was close to boiling point, despite the comments made by General Warouw with whom we spoke at the time. Evidence of that tension was reinforced when Bishop Belo made it clear in our meeting with him that at that very moment he was not permitted to visit some people who were in jail. The report made some quite sensible unanimous recommendations, including concern about the level of Indonesian military in East Timor, but it failed to press some of the issues that we would have liked. In particular, we felt that there needed to be international recognition of and discussion on East Timor. Certainly, from our point of view, we would have liked to have put forward the view that there should be an act of self-determination and, just as importantly, that we should change our stance at the UN by calling for these activities. The
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Allan Morris (Newcastle) (5.13 P.m.)
theText: In speaking on this motion on the UNMonday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10691 fact that that failed to get a majority recommendation will, I think, be to the shame of those who were involved. The report, on reading it now, is in some ways poignant. General Warouw was telling us then about the demonstrations of the previous year-these were not new things; they had been going on virtually annually and even more frequently-and he said that there were only a few stone throwings, that there was no big trouble, that it was not really serious, that it had all calmed down, that matters were very peaceful and that they were moving to ,persuasion. All those things were being said when that was obviously not the case when we were walking around the streets. I think the report referred to an unannounced visit to Viqueque. When we got there, because there was no forewarning, the people in the marketplace that we went to were absolutely terrified. They all hung back and everything came to a halt as soon as we arrived. In other places we had visited, things went on as normal and so the difference was obvious. When a late change of plan meant that we visited somewhere unannounced, the reaction of terror and apprehension by the community was absolutely paramount. As one of the few parliamentarians who had the responsibility of visiting East Timor on behalf of this parliament and who reported back, I am disappointed that more was not achieved as a result. In fact, after the report was tabled, some people saw the report as in some way authenticating-of course, it did not do that. With hindsight, I do not doubt that the four people who were opposed to that minority report would now regret their actions, but they could have been part of a changed attitude on both sides of this parliament and it is somewhat of a tragedy that they were not. I think this whole debate has now become something of an apology for the Howard government, and that is unfortunate. I suppose the old saying that, if you do not learn from history, you are bound to repeat it, has never been more relevant. Moving to the more current events, I will just read through a few of the headlines that we have been getting in recent times: from the West Australian, 'Timor, troops pay for PM's judgment'; the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 August, 'An open invitation to a bloodbath'; the Australian, 'A holocaust of Canberra's making'; the Canberra Times-not exactly a radical rag-'We should not have been surprised at events in East Timor'. An article in the Financial Review of 11 August, with the headline 'Good policy loses out to saving a neck', states: Saving Alexander's neck is now taking a precedence over good policy making in East Timor. Again, in early August an article in the Sydney Morning Herald talks about the Americans and says: A senior united Nations official told our foreign affairs department that Australia's attitude in East Timor was defeatist and that a peacekeeping operation would be necessary. In the Age News Extra on 11 September the headline reads 'Timor's pain; Australia's shame: why we kept Timor's secrets from the US.' The one that perhaps is the most striking is that of Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin of 21 September, 'Canberra's massacre we had to have'. All of those comments are in fact hurtful, but they go to the core of what we now have, which is an absolute catastrophe-a catastrophe for the East Timorese people, a catastrophe for the Indonesian people and a catastrophe for our country. This was without doubt the greatest disaster in Australian foreign policy ever-ofall time. We are playing with deckchairs on the Titanic as to whether we should have conscription, whether we should have 4,500 troops or 3,500 troops and whether they should be there for six months or nine months. The real issue is: firstly, how on earth do we win back the confidence of the people who used to 10692 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 see us as the experts on Indonesia and on Asian affairs and who trusted us and, secondly, how do we repair our relations with the rest of Asia? Our relations with Indonesia are dramatically affected, with the mQst recent events being the possible ban on purchasing Australian wheat, which we saw over the weekend. But that is no less so with the rest of Asia. Whilst Asian countries are involved in the peacekeeping activities-and I am delighted; I think we would all express our appreciation of that-the fact is that the idea that somehow we become a deputy sheriff for America in this region is absolutely appalling. The fact that that was not rebutted and refuted instantly and absolutely has meant that virtually every Asian country sees us as being the colonialists up to our old tricks and doing what we always wanted to do-help America in Korea, help America in Vietnam and now be America's deputy sheriff in the rest of Asia. (Time expired) and Resources) (5.24 p.m.)--The member for Newcastle has referred to a whole lot of newspaper headlines and to the more recent nonsense that was attributed to the Prime Minister regarding us being the deputy sheriff for the United States. I remind the honourable member that newspapers survive on sensationalism and, unfortunately, we have in this country nowprobably nationally-a situation where journalists are more interested in creating the news rather than reporting it. A lot of the nonsense that they tend to report, in my view, deliberately inflames the situation so that they can sell more newspapers. I suggest that we do not give them too much credibility. They certainly do not deserve it. Only yesterday I saw images of East Timor which distressed me immensely. One of our soldiers was handed a suspected militia man to apprehend. During the process of that fellow being secured on the ground I sawjournalists almost crawling over his back, and lying on their stomachs as they were jamming television cameras in the face of the militia man and in the face of one of our soldiers trying to do his job-absolutely disgraceful, and intimidating for our soldiers. A lot of this nonsense can clearly go back to the media. I rise today to support the Prime Minister in his efforts in the past few weeks to restore stability and peace to the South-East Asian region, particularly East Timor. I would also like to praise the efforts of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Alexander Downer, for his very hard work and skill in being able to convince the Indonesian government that a ballot should take place. There is absolutely no way on this earth that there would have been any movement to restore independence to East Timor if the people there had not been afforded the opportunity to show overwhelmingly that they wanted independence. There is no way that the international community would have come on board without that. Unfortunately, the people are going to pay a very high price for it, but at the end of the day they will certainly achieve that outcome. I commend the countries that have come on board-Thailand, Britain, New Zealand, et cetera-although I must say I was very disappointed with the United States for the time that it took. I believe that it could have responded a lot more quickly than it did, and we might well have been able to be in there a little bit more quickly. However, it is there now and is committed to supporting the United Nations peacekeeping force. For that I am very grateful. In Cairns we have quite a considerable population of East Timorese, about 300. When these events started to unfold, there was a lot of concern in the area, prompting the formation of the Cairns East Timorese Support Association. It has conducted a very effective public awareness campaign, including a number of public meetings to which it has been able to attract
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Entsch (Leichhardt
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, ScienceMonday, 27 September 1999 MAIN COMMITTEE 10693 quite a considerable number of people, and has been able to draw strong attention to the plight of the East Timorese people. One of the leaders and spokesmen, Antonio Pinto, has the very strong backing of a large group of people from Cairns, from a very broad range in the community. I have to congratulate them on the very proactive way in which they have acted, without resorting to racial or inflammatory tactics. What the group has done is very commendable, and I understand that several hundred are now involved in that support group. One of the things that is concerning me, and which is starting to unfold gradually, is the extent of the horrific crimes that have been inflicted on the East Timorese people. I must say I was very pleased to see the United Nations Human Rights Commissioner, Mary Robinson, come out with some very strong words on this issue. I think that we are going to have--from what I have been able to see--crimes against humanity of huge proportions. It is really going to throw a very bad light on the Indonesian military and some sections of the military in particular. I think that we have to be very careful when we are dealing with this that we do not point the finger at all of the Indonesian people. We should realise that it is only one small section of the population. In a media release today, the Australian Council of Overseas Aid, which represents all the non-government aid organisations, commented that Indonesian doctors in Australia are travelling to this area to offer their support. The fact that the Indonesian community in Australia is raising funds in support of the East Timorese is a wonderful thing. I would have thought, given the seriousness of this issue, that we would have had some sort of bipartisan support, particularly from the leadership on the other side. I was very disappointed when, on the first day of this debate, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, reverted to quotes of commentators in an effort to do some mudraking. The opposition leader made many hollow claims, the most hollow of all being that the intervention of the troops should have occurred earlier on. I have got to say that the Australian government as a whole has to accept some responsibility for what has happened here, and I say that successive governments for the last 25 years have been very reluctant to do anything. As I say, I am very proud to be part of a government that has been prepared to have the political will and the courage to get out there and actually start to do something. On 10 February 1999, Mr Beazley said that he 'would be against overseas deployment of Australian troops in circumstances where there was no agreement within the community that they wanted a peacekeeping role performed'. That was on 15 February this year and he was totally opposed to going in there before we were invited by the Indonesian regime. On2 March 1999, Stephen Martin, the shadow defence minister, said: You simply cannot commit troops in advance of a final system of Government being determined by the East Timorese people themselves. That is exactly what we had to do, and he acknowledged that on 2 March. Most importantly though, the shadow minister for foreign affairs, Laurie Brereton, has been ranting and raving about the fact that he had demanded sending a force prior to the ballot. This is the same man who, as Minister for Industrial Relations in 1993, said: I think one should not adopt the role of critic. One should, in acknowledgment of the vitally important bilateral relationship (with Indonesia) move in and assist wherever possible. 10694 MAIN COMMITTEE Monday, 27 September 1999 The shadow minister also went on to say: We hope that in tum we could help the development of our neighbourhood, a neighbourhood in which we see Indonesia as our most important partner. So they also played a very strong role in supporting the Indonesian regime back then. It is interesting to note that he is probably the only shadow foreign minister that I am aware of in Australia who has actually been told that he was not welcome in Indonesia. I suppose that highlights his ability as a diplomat. I am pleased that Alexander Downer was working at that time rather than the shadow minister for foreign affairs. In closing, I would just like to send my best wishes to the Australian troops. Let us not forget that they will be there for some time. They have a very strong risk of facing hostile fire, from what we have seen to date. For the time that they have been there, they have absolutely excelled themselves. Also, we must not forget the families-their loved ones who are sitting here waiting on tenterhooks that they return safely. I think it is important that we all get behind them 100 per cent with our best wishes and encouragement and, of course, wish them godspeed. Mr O'CONNOR (Corio) (5.34 p.m.)-All Australians cannot help but be moved by events as they have unfolded in East Timor. I think all Australians are horrified by the death and destruction that has been visited upon East Timor since the people of that area voted for their independence. The UN Security Council resolution we are debating here today sets out the parameters for the UN's involvement in East Timor, especially since the ballot for independence which was held recently. Australia is playing a central role as peacekeeper in the United Nations force which is now in East Timor and which has the responsibility of securing the peace and setting the conditions for a reconstruction of East Timorese society, both of the economy and the social framework. My interest in this part of the world goes back a long way. Since my university days, when I majored in Indonesian politics, I have had an interest in the affairs of our near neighbour to our north. I was also fortunate to visit East Timor in 1994 as part of an Australian parliamentary delegation that had attended an AIPO conference in the Philippines and had also visited Singapore and Indonesia.
